description.text: V3: Now with truly proper clearance! (v1 was too tight to print parts larger than 3-4" dia, V2 was better but still not right) Board now mounts on the "IN" SIDE of the part; the side without the beveling. Thermocouple board mount that allows an Ultimaker TC1 board to be mounted on top of the extruder platform of a RoStock MAX V2. The boardsare mounted to my remixed dual extruder platform (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:707701) however the hole spacing should allow for it to mount directly to the stock platform as well. On a side note, I desoldered the barrier diode and put a jumper in on my board. The diode was shifting the ground ref by a diode drop (Schottky, so around 250mV) and causing everything to read ~25C off. (And since I was already hard-wired I deemed it safe to bypass the reverse current protection...)

Holes for platform mounting are #6-32 clearance (0.144) however they printed tight on our uPrint so the threads did engage the part.   The board mounting holes are #4-40 tap drill (0.089) but can easily be bumped out around ten thousandths for an M3x0.5 which is what we did here using a #40 drill.  
Mount the print to the platform FIRST, then mount the TC board to the print.  It sucks to do it this way, but the screw clearance don't work if you mount the TC board first... (My bad design)

comments.text: Thanks for another part in your Rostock Max dual extruder series!  I wrapped your V3 STL with an OpenSCAD file to extend the mount up a little bit and put in a hole pattern for the E3D TC board, and I posted it as a remix in case anyone else has the same board.
comments.author: gravatite

comments.text: What's the advantage of effector mounting the amplifier board? Would the additional wiring resistance to reach the inside of the base cause an inaccuracy?
comments.author: jimustanguitar

comments.text: The advantage was purely personal and in point of fact 597 amplifiers prefer a bit more resistance rather than less (you can, in fact, have too short of a thermocouple; the 597 assumes you've shorted the input and goes into self-measurement mode).
comments.author: jimustanguitar

title: Quill light for bridgeport clone mill
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
**Update 2***
The LEDs that I ordered from amazon fit PERFECT (5mm, ultrabright white, 0.02ma 3.2-3.4v). If you wire the LEDs in sets of 4, and then parallel them all together, a 15v power suppy will power them without resistors. The channels worked perfect for the legs of the LEDs, it took about 4 hours to do all of the wiring and soldering of the lights. Hooked it up to the bridgeport and what do you know, no more shadows on my mill! I am very happy with how it ended up, I think this is the first thing I have ever made that worked the first time the way I planned it. I will take pictures of the wiring and the light working later. There are two sections where the slots are not as wide as the rest, I didn't realize that until after I started wiring (you will see it in the pictures). update the 5mm LED's are too tight, at least with my printer. I would recommend 3mm LEDs for those who have already downloaded the part. Took about 4.5 hours to print with a makerbot on normal (0.2mm layer). It has a nice tight fit on the quill, you almost don't need the magnets. I might rework the part to make the holes larger, we will see how motivated I am. Quill light for bridgeport clone mill. Solidworks file and .stl file. Uses 90 5mm led lights. I haven't printed this yet so the hole tolerances might be tight. Save yourself $$, these sell for $140 on ebay. 100 ultra bright led's cost $10 on amazon. Holes on top/inside vertical surface are for (8) 1/4" neodymium magnets. The bottom side is beveled out for .122" plexiglass. Inner hole diameter is 2.2" outer diameter is 4.2" if you want to make a plexiglass cover for the lights.
Solidworks and 2 lime freeze rockstars

comments.text: Great idea, I have been wanting to make one for ages. Could you tell me the centre hole diameter please. Also, is there a wiring diagram available, I'm useless at electronics. Many thanks.

title: DailyEarring#63: Micro Pinball Machine (2x3cm)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
-DailyEarrings+Prologue: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7120 A tiny pinball machine! And it works (at least as far as it can work on this scale). This is as small as I could make it regarding the pp3dp's limitations and the function.
It's all a bit close together, but still has multiple features: -Two flippers
-Edges resembling Slingshot bouncers which block the direct way to the targets
-2 Targets wich slide out to indicate score
-Two bumper on an axis and unsemetric center so they bounce (bump) back
-Ball plunger (flick up to get the ball back into the game) At this scale, at least with this material and this printer, a spring and other components where not possible.
If you have any other ideas, please share! I'dd also like to see a larger version with more gimmicks. Files include: STL
Printing files Sketchup/SKP:
-A Previous, larger version
-Multiple versions/orientations for printing in one piece or as assembly set NOTE: 3D pictures lack some minor modifications which I added later on. TODO:
  • Under-board to the indicators
  • Indicator need to be thicker to not slide out
  • More play on axis
  • Perhaps use BB instead of plastic ball
  • thicker plunger base
  • More room (upside) for the bumpers
    • NOTE:
    Colored version is just an example. I will print the edited version and paint the parts prior to assembly... some day.

1- Either try to print the assembled version (have fun cleaning support material out), or print the single parts 2- Carefully (!) widen the holes a bit (tweezers etc.), then assemble 3- glue the frame on-top. 4- Color the thing in some cool neon colors for a funky & retro 80's look and feel! 5- Cut a sheet of clear plastic (acrylic, packaging, document organizer...) and glue it into the frame (max 25.8mm x 19.7mm, simply trace it with the top-frame). Make sure to drop some glue on the flipper/bumper axis too so it will stick to the plastic, increasing durability. 4- Reset the Score counter, shoot the ball into the game, and play! NOTE:
The version to assemble has slightly thicker flipper/bumper axes as the tolerance can be lower as the one-piece version.
1mm/1.3mm is still rather thin, so if you do not want earrings, you should scale it up. As allways I want to add, that I am doing a set of earings daily. This means that the files may not print correctly due to errors and such. On pp3dp use the "print unsolid models" option.

title: iPhone 6 Plus Universal CD Slot Adapter

description.text:
Hello all. I designed this after not finding one to fit my needs. It is a universal holder, and should work with a variety of iPhone 6 Plus cases. I personally have 8 different style of cases for this phone and it fits all of them, with some looser fitting than others.   
The slot adapter was designed to fit the GPS radio in my 2008 GMC Yukon, but it should also fit other GM cars and trucks as well. It is a nice tight fit and shouldn't wiggle out. The bottom of the phone holder has a large hole so you can easily connect your charger or headphone jack. I also made it with a dovetail type joint for easy assembly. It fits very snug and should not require glue, unless you want to use some. At the top, there is a stop, so it can't go all the way through.   
I was able to print this on my printer with no support, and a very tiny amount of cleanup was required on the slot piece from the first bridged layer at the back of the dovetail joint. This took less than 5 minutes.   
Let me know if you like it, or if you need any changes made. I have included the Autodesk 123D Design files if you want to modify it yourself. Enjoy!

author: mkyrish

description.text:
When printing very small features that need to fit together, you can't always trust the printer's accuracy. For example, a 2mm hole turns out to be a bit less than 2mm, while a 2mm stud is a bit more. To make the two fit together snugly, I had to increase the hole size to 2.4mm for the specific printer settings I was using.  
This Thing will print a gauge with holes and studs so you can select the correct values for a specific object you are trying to print.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6VST4m9GLzY
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:78719 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=78719

Using the following options: lithophane_border = 0
number_of_layers = 12
hole_border = 0
image_file = lithopaneatoz20150320-16191-11v455s-0.dat
layer_height = 0.2
hole_diameter = 0

On Earth, organisms including fish, reptiles, birds and mammals all share the same basic body plan - 4 limbs with 5 digits on each, a head with two eyes and a mouth, etc. If you started with a different body plan, and tried to explore permutations to occupy different ecological niches, what would you come up with? These creatures are a thought experiment, they are all descended from the same 6 legged "ancestor" skeleton, made with 123D Creature. This came out of a brainstorming session about how to use 123D Creature in teaching evolutionary biology, taking advantage of the feature that lets you re-use a skeleton and then sculpt a different creature.

You can just print these critters as is. They will need to have support material enabled. I made sure to give their feet flat bottoms, so they should stick nicely to the build platform. If you have the 123D Creature iPad app, you can open them from the community (search for "mars evolution"), or you can open the "ancestor" skeleton and make your own variations.

description.text:
Vol trots presenteer ik je nu ein-de-lijk mijn zelfontworpen dubbele tapedispenser/plakbandhouder/plakband'automaat'!
(Hoe je het ook noemen wil...) Tijdens de ontwerplessen moesten we in zo'n 5 minuten 2 verschillende plakbandhouders schetsen/ontwerpen. En 1 daarvan was deze in enkele vorm. Gewoon voor 1 rol. Toen ik het daarna ging tekenen, eerst in SpaceClaim, kwam ik er achter dat als ik het wat breder zou maken, er 2 rollen in zouden passen en het dan aan beide kanten gebruikt kan worden!
Géén idee of het al bestaat, maar hoe dan ook is dit mijn ontwerp geworden! Vóórdat we het zouden gaan printen, moesten we er een model van maken. Dat kon uit klei, karton, of waardan ook mee.. Ik heb gekozen voor karton.
Na 3 uur tekenen, rekenen, snijden en plakken had ik ik van karton mijn eigen plakbandhouder op ware grootte geknutseld! (Zie collage 2) Maar het moest ook geprint worden en afgelopen weekend had ik dus de 3D-printer thuis en is het me gelukt om het uit te printen! Helaas zitten hier geen goede snijtanden aan, omdat ik die mee moest modelleren, dus daardoor is het meer een sierobject dan een functioneel product. Verder had hij als functioneel product ook verzwaard moeten worden. Dit heb ik overwogen om het tijdens het printen met zand te vullen, maar er vanaf gezien omdat het toch voor de sier zou worden. De kartonnenversie doet het beter, want daar heb ik van 2 zeer goedkope plakbandhouders van de A. de snijrandjes uitgehaald en er in gezet, dus die doet het wel! title: Prusa i3 Plate mounted dual spool filament holder

description.text: Mount two spools of filament on your aluminium plate (6mm) Prusa i3.

Print two of the dual plate mounts and 4 of the spindle holders. Cut four lengths of M6 and two lengths of M8 threaded rod ~ 150mm long. Fit two of the M6 threaded rods to each plate mount with M6 nuts and washers. Fit a spindle holder to the other end of each M6 threaded rod. Print four spool adapters ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:60723 ), fit two to each spool along with the M8 threaded rod and drop that into the spindle holders.

author: MarkBenson

description.text:
This is an airship I designed for a steampunk D&D game.  
It is scaled just a bit small for 28mm minis. If you plan to use it in a game you should scale it up to probably at least 130%.  
It should hold maybe 6 or so minis; it should feel a bit tight for the minis, even though the print is a pretty huge one! I'm still new to modeling, so it's very simple in design; nothing too intricate or beautiful.  You could probably decorate it with barrels, ropes, or mounted ballistae to make it into a neat warship.  
I haven't tried printing it yet... I cut it into pieces that hopefully will be easy to print, but I have no idea. If you try printing it, please let me know how it goes!  
Edit: I have started printing, and as I suspected the support ropes gave me some trouble, so I have detached them from the hull and uploaded them separately. Good luck!

title: Taranis Antenna Mod - no dremel required

description.text:
PLEASE NOTE: use RG316 or RG178 coax cable with female RPSMA connector. This is per IBCrazy's recommendation. When you use the thinner stuff it just bleeds a ton of signal and you get really bad range.
UPDATE: It works great. Enjoy.  
The other part like this suggests using a hacksaw and a dremel to modify the antenna hole on the top of the Taranis. I wasn't satisfied with this as it is much simpler to print a part that fits the existing hole.  
Instead of a hacksaw, I used a flush cut saw which is much finer and cuts that plastic like butter. I used that to cut the two rings that remain after you remove the stock antenna, cutting down flush with the top of the case. This leaves a ring of plastic and a 9mm hole; half of that plastic ring is intended to slot into the other side of the radio case. I then made a cut along the seam of the case so as to remove that ring; after a line was cut I just snipped off the plastic with a pair of flush cutters and tidied it up with a razor.  
When you join the cases, you end up with an opening which is comprised of a half circle 9mm in diameter and and the other side is ~13mm. This part is designed to fit in that slot perfectly. In order for the SMA connector to fit well, and for there to be plenty of thread exposed, I shifted the hole off center. There are two supports that fit the taranis case and support the antenna.

comments.text: Worked great thanks!!
comments.author: Problex

comments.text: This design is very good. I printed it on a Flashforge Dreamer. 15% infill with 0.2 layer height, didn't use any supports. One of the round structures sagged a little bit though, so perhaps need a little bit of support at the area where the RPSMA connector is. I had to do some filing for the two cylinders on each side, but overall it was a good fit and the design leads to stronger antenna mounting point than the other ones posted here. Thanks!

description.text:
I've added two "rafts" at the ends of the model where the bolts go through to make it easier when printing in ABS.
The model has a tendency to lift on one end probably due to its length and wall thickness, no matter what I did, even having the raft set in makerware, it was still lifting at the one end, the bed adhesion was okay too, it was well and truly stuck on the other end.
So I figured the model needed more surface area on those two ends to stay stuck without requiring a full raft.

author: Antsurkov

title: Drill Bit Sorting Gauge - Laser Cut

description.text: A gauge for sorting drill bits by size.  Slip the bit into the slot and slide it towards the small end until it stops.  Read off the size to the nearest 1/64nd of an inch.

Will probably require a little tuning for your laser, depending on the beam kerf. Recommended for thick (6mm+ acrylic). Note: this is a VERY LARGE gauge (24" wide) to allow for ease of use. Cut out one copy, then use some known-sized drill bits to check the alignment of the grid to the slot. If needed move the grid to the left or right until the marks align with the bit size and reprint. Once calibrated to your laser's beam, you can cut out as many copies as your like for your friends. Black is for thru-cutting the acrylic. Red is for etching. Specific settings will depend on your laser. The grid and the labeling are grouped in Inkscape so one can move them left or right by selecting and using the arrow keys (or alt+arrow key for smaller movements. Inspired by an idea by Brandon Green at the Dallas Makerspace (http://www.dallasmakerspace.org)

title: mendel spring design for soft PLA springs

description.text:
This is an alternative design for mendel springs printed with soft PLA. Because the standard mendel springs printed with ABS break, if you squeeze them to much and loose their springiness, I tried to print them using soft PLA. But soft PLA is springy itself and thus the spring is not hard enough anymore. So I designed a soft PLA spring which is hard enough but very springy and doesn't break if you squeeze it to much. The first design was just as springy as the standard ones which were not satisfying when printed with soft PLA. But the mirrored ones are fantastic. More about this on www.ifeelbeta.de Greetings
BonsaiBrain Edit: openSCAD source file uploaded - it's no professional code, but parametric
Print the spring with soft PLA!

title: Metal Simple Printrbot  Filament Holder (Sturdy)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: DESCRIPTION

This sturdy filament holder prints best upright without supports and with 0.2mm layer height with 30% infill.  
Simple bent paperclips and a couple of 50-cent clamps make for a sturdy, reliable filament management system for the Printrbot Metal Simple.
CREATION

• Print the STL file provided at the default scaling (if using your Printrbot Simple Metal, compare to screenshot of prepped build plate to detect scaling issues. STL files carry absolute lengths so there should be no issues, but if necessary use spacing of holes at bottom of holder to rescale the print)

  • Bend paperclips into shape shown in gallery with wire cutters and needle-nosed pliers

  • Heat up ends of clips on stove and push into the tops of the two vertical arms as pictured.

  • Cut 13cm of 1-1/2" PVC pipe (I used black ABS) or another low-thickness pipe with an outer diameter between 4cm and 5cm (the OD must be between 4cm and 5cm to ensure both clearance through the filament reel AND elevation of the reel off the bottom of the holder)

  • You're done! Place holder on vertical rods (use grease if necessary). Secure filament by inserting PVC pipe through filament and placing on vertical arms, then clamping using small clamps like this (http://tinyurl.com/ofqr7g3) found at your local hardware store.

title: 2 Liter Bottle to 1/2" PVC Pipe Adapter

description.text: In keeping with Kludgemonkey's wishes (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13826), this is a remix of his Bottle Cap Start that adapts a bottle cap to a piece of 1/2" PVC pipe. I used it to make the HowToons Stomp Rocket from MAKE Magazine volume 42. Instead of duct taping the bottle to the PVC pipe, the bottle screws onto the adapter, which fits on the PVC pipe. This way the smashed bottle can be unscrewed, reshaped, and reattached with ease.

Printed at .3mm layer height, one shell, on a MakerBot Thing-O-Matic with an MK6+ extruder and Sailfish firmware. 3mm ABS MakerBot filament.  
There is built-in support in the center of the adapter that I easily removed with a pair of needle nose pliers.  
I wrapped duct tape around the PVC pipe three times to give the adapter a snug fit on the pipe.

title: Filament Spool - fully printable - supportless - needs double sided tape

description.text:
I just got a new 0.5kg PLA filament spool and needed a spoolstand for it. I didn't have any metal parts at home, but I couldn't find an entirely screw free filament spool holder.  
So I made everything printable. I just finished it after about 5 hours of work. Hope you all like it.  
It was very careful to make it printable without support structure.  
Depending on how well you printer is calibrated with regards to the bridges you should have no problem printing this design.  
The design requires to be glued onto a surface. I am using the powerstrips from tesa (see picture). These should have no problem holding it. Alternatively double sided tape should do the trick.

In parts that require bridges to be build use a small file to remoove material that is hanging into the tube. You can see the process in the pictures.
You need to print the stls with an _x2 behind the name twice to be able to assemble the structure.
The rods fit snugly into the corresponding tubes. In my case I didn't need to use glue. But be careful once a rod is inserted into a tube it is almost impossible to remove it again. So I would recommend printing all the parts and laying out each tube before you jam them together.
Download the "Fully printable spool stand stl.zip" file to get all the different STL's you need at once.
Minimum print platform is 14x14cm

author: jbabio

description.text:
élément de guidage Z pour bcn3d+  
pour évité une flexion des barres de guidage et de la tige filetée

This is very much a work in progress. The goal of this project is to create a robot which can "print" designs with Perler Beads automatically. The raw material would be multicolored unsorted Perler beads. The robot would accept a bitmap image with some pixel art you'd like to recreate in Perler beads. It would automatically sort the beads and place them on a grid, ready to iron. So far... I have a blog post explaining some of my ideas so far:
http://scanlime.org/2011/02/perler-bead-robot-ideas/ And another post about the color sensor I plan to use:
http://scanlime.org/2011/02/trying-out-the-avago-adjd-s371-q999-color-sensor/ A video of the vibrating funnel in action:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/micahdowty/5407791891/in/set-72157625540465089/ The design comes in several "layers" which stack vertically with standard M4 hardware. First there is a hopper for the raw unsorted beads, then a vibrating funnel which extracts the beads in single-file. Next, a sorter which includes a color sensor, and a servo-driven disc which shuttles the beads back and forth at the right time. This will sit above some kind of X-Y table, which can be rather simple given the low precision requirements. Currently the first two layers, the hopper and the vibrating funnel, are mostly done. The sorter is more of a sketch than a final design at this point, and it will probably change significantly.

Aluminum cast in ABS mold. Link to an earlier casting project, with pewter, zinc and lead.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:286521

I've been doing some more metal casting in ABS molds lately, and on the spur of the moment, decided to try aluminum. I long ago deleted this mold's STL files, and can't post them but they are not important. It's a very simple mold. There's a tall core which forms the inside of the casting and a 2-sided box that forms the outer diameter. The sprue is just a long square hole, feeding from the bottom up. I never intended to use this print as a mold for metal casting. It is a terrible design for the purpose. But it did have thick sections and that's what I was curious about. Aluminum is not at all fluid compared to some alloys and it won't flow and fill thin sections by gravity alone. But thick parts contain so much heat I was not anticipating any sort of success. Aluminum (an unknown alloy) was poured at 1250F. That's hotter than it needed to be, but I wanted to see what would happen. Among other defects due to a high temperature, the surface is rough and might be much better if it were poured cooler. However, it may not be possible since the plastic mold virtually evaporates, and gases may always cause bubbles, roughness and various surface defects. The mold inside diameter was designed to be 1 inch. The casting ID is 0.99 inch. Mold's outer dia was 1.25", and the casting result was 1.215". So it shrunk quite a bit for a small casting.
But it did come out nice and round. There was much smoke but no flames. A greyish, stinking smoke but with none of the black soot from setting ABS on fire. I'd estimate about 100+ cigarettes might produce the same cloud volume. After a few moments the very hot, very soft mold was dumped into a bucket of water. It steamed and sizzled for a minute. This was an experiment to explore materials and possibilities. Results are completely unpredictable and therefore it's very dangerous. Do not try this. Don't even think about metal casting unless you have the proper equipment, and know and follow all the safety rules and requirements. One false move and it's ambulances, cops and / or fire engines. PS The ornament STL file uses Imperial measurements. If metric print software imports it as a tiny 2 mm diameter, which is likely, scale it up by a factor of 25.4. Or as big as you like i guess....

comments.text: Very interesting reading all of these comments.  Here I am, learning about metal casting on a 3d printing site.  Whoda thunk it?  Very cool!

comments.text:
Very. This one amazed me. My first try using aluminum. I could hardly believe it.
The melt temperature should be just barely above freezing, so it quickly freezes (solidifies) when poured into the mold; Freezes before too much plastic mold surface melts and is destroyed..
Have fun.
comments.author: bbushong

comments.text:
Just wanted to post and say that after seeing how successful these have been I've attempted similar projects.
I've had moderate success casting a low melting point tin/bismuth alloy directly into abs.
The metal I am using melts at around 280F and I water quench the entire mold quickly after pouring.
I've been able to retain fine detail such as individual layers with this method, plus I feel a little bit more comfortable working with 300F metal rather then 1200F+ metal.

I agree that casting low temperature metals is the way to begin. It's not only safer, but many of the basic techniques practiced can be applied to higher temperature alloys. Like just designing a mold that works is half the battle.

comments.text:
I design with Blender. Freeware, with a huge support community, from wikis to perhaps thousands of Youtube videos.
For 3D printing purposes, we need to learn perhaps only 1% (or less) of its capabilities. "Boolean" operations, add subtract one shape from another. I use that more than anything else. It can do 3D animations, renderings, and so forth, but the community did add a 3D Printing "module" just for us, because so many people use it.
comments.author: jordam

comments.text: Rest assured I'm not going to try this myself... I'm just throwing out ideas. I just figured that a 10% change in the temperature of the mould might be significant.
comments.author: frankvdh

comments.text:
Casting metal is a very interesting hobby, and I encourage people to try it.
And I'm not only talking to you, but to all the kids out there, so forgive me if it seems like I'm talking to some kid :-) I mean no disrespect.
comments.author: frankvdh

comments.text: My method with this is to use the ABS part as a lost wax type, coat the part in ceramic and then fire it and the ABS smokes out leaving the female shape. Then set the ceramic mould in sand and pour the part inside. Interesting that you actually got a part out of it, nice.
comments.author: DGA

comments.text:
Lost wax preserves the detail so it's definitely the way to go. I've done a bit of it.
... searched for something to dissolve the ABS without heat, rather than burn it out. But gasoline, acetone, etc just aren't fast and effective enough.
Beyond ABS burnout annoyances, the plastic pattern is so difficult to model compared to wax, I just gave it up on it.
comments.author: DGA

comments.text: What about using a dissolvable filament like HIPS?
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
Sounds like it could work. I never had any to experiment with. Your guess is as good as mine. Maybe someone is already doing it?
Off the top of my head I see one or two potential problems.
comments.author: legreatmagnet

comments.text: I wonder whether deep-freezing the PLA beforehand would help? Maybe even freeze with dry ice?
comments.author: frankvdh

comments.text:
Frank.. One more idea to clarify.
Water goes through a phase change from liquid to solid at 32F. That releases tons of heat, but the temperature does not drop.
comments.author: frankvdh

comments.text:
That could be very dangerous.
I'll say this again because it cannot be overstressed. Don't even try this (or metal casting in general) unless you have a good grasp of metal casting. There are many hidden dangers.
comments.author: frankvdh

comments.text: OK wondering how you did this, why didn't the ABS turn into gas with molten aluminium poured into it?
comments.author: DGA

comments.text:
well.... much of the ABS did melt and gassify (if that's a word). It smoked badly.
But as long as the aluminum surface has already solidified, which it does in an instant, the mold is no longer needed. It can melt or whatever without affecting the hardened aluminum shape within it.

description.text:
Happen to miss a lot of notifications when my phone is on silent. So I have to find a way to make it stand in front of me while I'm staring at a computer screen. Might not be an issue when everyone gets their Apple Watch that vibrate on your wrist. But still, you could forget to wear it once in a while. You'll still need this on the day that you forget to wear your smartwatch :)  
Designed to be a loose fit without a case. A snug fit will require taping it on the desk or use two hands to remove the phone, something I wanted to avoid.  
Can't seem to find a minimalist design that I like on Thingiverse, so I made this simple stand.

15% infill is good enough.
printed in under 80 minutes @ 0.4mm layer.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/isN1Oqgx7xw Why? Because now you can have an answer to those nosy people wondering, "How long will it take to print?" :)

author: MechanicMeow

description.text:
After working with the earlier Slinky Seismometer parts I'd made (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:172657), I set out to make an easier to build model. These parts can be connected by 1/4 inch nylon threaded rods and held in place with nylon nuts. (You can't use metal rods, as the magnets in the middle will be attracted to metal rods, which will mess up the seismometer.) More information about the TC-1 Slinky Seismometer can be found here:
http://tc1seismometer.wordpress.com/

In order to construct a Slinky Seismometer from these models, you will need to print the following at a minimum: BaseRing.stl: This acts as the foot, and is where you'll place the adjustable feet for leveling and centering.
DamperRetainerRing.stl: This is where you put the piece of copper pipe that acts as a damper for the spring motion. The ring can accept a 2 inch section of 1 inch diameter pipe, or a 1 inch to 3/4 reducer coupling.
WireSpoolRing.stl: This is where you wrap the copper wire for the pickup coil. There are wings where you can attach 6-32 screws to act as terminals. I attach the wire from the coil to the top side of the screw, then attach the wire out to the amplifier board on the bottom side.
TopCap.stl or ExtendedTopCap.stl: Pick one of these. This is where you'll attach the Slinky Retainer piece.
TC1SlinkyRetainer.stl: The extra slinky coils are held in place here, and you can adjust this up or down based on the magnet position. That's all you need to print. You can print as many BasicSupportRing.stl copies as you need for stability. For a short model, you might not need any, but you'll probably want one every foot or so. The rings are all connected with 1/4 inch nylon threaded rod, and held in place by nylon nuts. You want to use nylon because metal rods will either attract the magnet or introduce additional damping, both of which are bad. More information about the additional parts needed for assembly (The magnets, the Slinky Jr., etc.), as well as a compatible Arduino based amplifier can be found here: https://tc1seismometer.wordpress.com/ (Note: I am not affiliated with the creators of the TC-1. I just built one of these seismometers and wanted to make printable parts to make the assembly easier.)

comments.text:
Hello, I finally found a suitable copper coil and a slinky jr so I can start this project !
However something remains unclear to me from your design and TC-1 blog : what is the use of the damper tube ??
Thanks a lot!
comments.author: Gilles31

comments.text: If you don't have the damper, the slinky will keep bouncing for minutes after any movement, and you'll get a lot of noise.  With the damper (and the second magnet inside), the slinky will quickly stop moving unless something (like an earthquake) keeps moving it.
comments.author: Gilles31

description.text:
First project built from scratch. Its a fully functional CONNECT 4 complete with a dump bar at the bottom to let all the pieces fall out.  
It is a snap together design i printed with PLA (so i dont know how it will work with ABS Shrinkage)

You need 2x connect4 Board x2.stl 8x connect4 Joiner x8.stl 1x connect4 Dump Bar x2.stl 21x connect4 Piece x21 x2.stl
and in a different color another
21x connect4 Piece x21 x2.stl 2x connect4 Holder x2.stl Attach the joiners to one side of the board (they fit only one way) Put the "DUMP BAR" into the groove (doesnt matter which way it goes) Place the other side on top and position the jointers in place (dump bar should also fit in place) Press HARD to snap it all together Put down the two base parts so the it is flat and simply slide the board into the groove.
sitting buddha

title: Endcaps for the OneTesla TS Tesla Coil

description.text:
Using the pieces of cut acrylic as endcaps caused a very nasty case of internal flashing which nearly destroyed my secondary.  Most of the problem, in my guess, was that the wires went inside the secondary and there wasn't much resistance between it.  Also, the original setup created shear points between the acrylic and the PVC of the secondary causing the wire to break easily if twisted or pushed in wrong.  
My solution was to create endcaps that you could install into the secondary while still gaining access to the bolt where the wire goes, and also keep the metal out of the tube.    This seems to work great.
Created in SolidWorks as a test.  My first attempt.  Tolerances might not be perfect, but they worked for me.  I had to shave some parts down, but it wasn't bad.  Pretty happy results for my first attempt at something like this.

Print 2 copies of Endcap.STL and Center_Plug.STL.
Print one copy of Bottom_Plate.STL and Top_Plate.STL.
You should have 2 bolts that are used to go into the endcap.  Then you can plug the endcap with the center plug.
The wires from the endcap should go into the groove and bolted down.  Then place the plates on the ends.  There are indentations that go into holes on the endcaps to keep it from spinning.
The bottom end plate has extra grooves that go into the screw holes to keep it from turning.  The top plate is smooth and goes directly against the toroid.

comments.text: A friend printed this for me, but the bottom endcap's pegs don't line up with the holes on my board (or the leftover remains of my acrylic cap that I really should have hot-melt glued instead of super-gluing).
comments.author: dlgeek

comments.text: Hey, I don't have the measurements I took right now.  I used calipers and did a couple test prints to get them to match the holes in the board.  Unless something has changed in the last year, which is unlikely, they should still fit.  Maybe I'll try to print them out again and see.
comments.author: dlgeek

comments.text: I get about 35.3mm between 2 holes on the acrylic endcap and 33.2mm between the bases of the pegs of my printed Bottom Endcap. I haven't been able to get a good measurement out of FreeCad for loading the STL file, and I don't have SolidWorks to try it on the original files.

Bayley is saying that the added space between the primary and secondary can cause some issues. Do you get a nice functioning coil with the end cap so tall? Mine seems to be working fine in low power test but not when powered up.
What do you think about reducing the height of the Endcap to a couple of mm so that it is closer to the primary?

Otherwise, feel free to edit it yourself.  Shouldn't be difficult and I'm sure Bayley knows better than I do on tolerances.

comments.text:
The instructions are very clear now, thank you. I have used the top end cap for the bottom by mistake because I was missing the bottom plate, when ready I'll simply flip the coil and should be fine.
Two notes on the bolt and how protect it. I have threaded the bolt through the endcap, then I used one of the two nuts to lock it in place, this fits nicely in the indentation provided. Then I added the ring which I then secure with a second nut. Finally, I hot glue in place the center plug which will completely isolate the bolt from the inside of the coil.
I bought a pack of two M6 1 nuts at HD and use one each to secure the coil and the toroid.

Maybe it's not bad, but I didn't like it.  However, since designing this cap for the bottom, I haven't had any internal flashes, so that's a win.

description.text: This trebuchet uses a floating arm rather than a fixed arm. That means that the weights can fall completely vertical resulting in a more efficient and powerful throw compared to standard trebuchet designs. See a test firing shot here: http://i.imgur.com/9QZHuB0.gif It requires 2 toothpicks, some string, and 32 dimes to fill the weights.

Assembly should be fairly straight forward. You will need 2 toothpicks and 2 and 10-15cm of string along with the 3d printed parts. You need to print two of the weight, the stand, and the wheel. Everything else just print 1. You will need to orient each shape properly as I did not build them on the plane they were to be printed at.  
I printed the parts at 0.025mm height with 0.05mm width. Some parts are small and are exactly 1mm in width so these settings ensure that they match up exactly with no small gaps.  
side1 and side2 should pushed together until they are flush. This might be a bit hard, but this is to ensure that they stay in place and will not come apart. I used a small vice to push pins together that I couldn't get with my hands. The stands just snap on to the assembled frame.  
The sling should just snap together. Once the 2 halves are together make sure they swing freely. If they do not you may need to make some small edits to the file to get the piece configured correctly for your printer. These are small pieces so some variation may occur. The current size of the hole and pin worked great for me. The hinge stays together and swings loosely so the coin can fly out with no resistance.  
For the arm take one of your toothpicks and cut it in half. One half will be your firing pin so save that for later. With the other half but it down to 9mm in length. This goes through the hole that is second from the top of the arm (top being the thickest end of the arm). Next push the two wheels, one to each end of the toothpick. The other toothpick secures the weights and the arm to the frame. It goes through one vertical slit, then through the top most hole of the arm, the through the far slit. Once this is done you can slide the weights onto each side and fill the weights with dimes. You could increase the size of the weight holders if you want to use pennies or some other denomination.  
For the string...one piece goes through the bottom most hole of the arm and then through one of the string holes on the sling. Another piece of string must be made into a loop on one end and the attached to the other string hole on the sling. When loaded, the sling should be about in the center of the frame with the strings taut. Too long and it will not have enough power to swing the strings, too short and it will throw your coins into the ground every time. Experiment a bit to find that sweet spot.  
If you have any trouble just look up how trebuchets work and you should be able to sort it out.

description.text:
I came across this calculator for an acoustic diffusor and whipped up a basic static model of it: http://www.mh-audio.nl/DiffusorCalculator3.asp My model has a column width of 1cm and max column length of 1cm, which results in low and high frequencies of 17200 Hz, and you can scale the model to tailor it to your needs: Z scale factor = 17200 / desired low frequency (Hz)
X,Y scale factor = 17200 / desired high frequency (Hz) Put another way: Low frequency (Hz) = 17200 / Z scale factor
High frequency (Hz) = 17200 / X,Y scale factor For example, suppose your 3D printer can print an object 10cm high: this gives a min frequency of 1720 Hz. If the smallest reliable size you can print a 10cm-tall square post is, say, 0.5cm on a side, then this gives a high frequency of 34400 Hz. Just use scale factors of 10 (Z) and 0.5 (X,Y). Easy peasy. Disclaimer: I'm not really an audio guy and haven't had a chance to test this yet! Thought it looked cool though.

Developed this support due to my need, because I wanted to have something to support my tablet to watch videos in a convenient position without holding it, and he could carry it easily to where it was. Therefore, it would have reduced dimensions.
Hence created this support, based on a cassette box. I made some adjustments in order to position the tablet in the desired angle, both for watching videos, how to enter.
To position the inclination to watch videos, adjusts the moving part, so as to match the latch into hole on base, and then moves to lock this hole. Thus, the part that supports the tablet is fixed.
I took the box to include an adaptation to save a headset ear, which is located on the bottom base of the box.
To store the headset in the box that has four pins internally, initially set up the two earphones in a recess, and then wraps the wire in these four pins. The photos illustrate how to do this.
So in addition to being able to watch videos on the tablet resting in the cradle, you can also enter by simply leaning over the cap, and also store the headset in a practical way. For those who want to contact me, I leave my email is available, which is [email protected]

The entire Mobile Holder for Tablet is composed of three parts. Box, lid and latch.
The files are in stl format. Those who wish can resize it according to your need.

This is my third generation virtual reality headset.  The primary feature introduced this time is a detachable cradle for the phone.  This allows you to quickly remove the phone to switch apps, answer a call, etc.  Additionally, it makes it very easy to add support for other phones.  Currently I have cradles for a Samsung Note4 with and without an Otter Box enclosure. Others will follow.  If you are impatient, I uploaded the cradle base with all the features required to connect to the goggles so other makers can easily build their own cradles for any device they choose.

I will improve the instructions and add additional lens and phone options along and along. To build, you need to print the following at 0.2mm layer height:
1) TTVR - this is the main headset. No supports or brim required (included in the model).
2) TTVRCradle - either Note4Bare(Note4, no case) or Note4OB (Note4 with an Otterbox enclosure).
3) LensmmX2 - you will need a pair of lens holders to fit the lenses chosen. No supports or brim required.
4) clips - a complete set of clips required for hands-free operation. No supports or brim required. Additionally, you will need: 1) a pair of convex lenses with 38-48mm diameter and 45-56mm focal length. If you need room for glasses, then stay on the low end (45-50 mm) of focal length. http://www.surplusshed.com has a great selection at amazing prices (typically $4.50/ea). I am currently using 45.1mm diameter double convex (DCX) lenses with 55.8mm focal length and these seem about perfect for me (no glasses).
2) 1.5" elastic
3) 3/4" weather stripping
4) Two 1/2" X 1/8" button magnets The TTVRCradleBaseNoPrint.stl is just the hardware required to connect to the headset for anyone who wishes to make a cradle for another device. You just need to add a pocket of the correct size. http://youtu.be/7GRXhtJYJaE
http://youtu.be/DKPF3DwYxHE

title: Retainer ring removal tool for a Saab fuel pump

description.text:
Here's a tool I made to take out the retainer ring for a Saab fuel pump. Took forever to print (8-9 hours, 0.3mm layers, 25% hex infill, PLA on a Printrbot Simple Metal with a brim) and took up most the build volume, but printed perfectly. It's for a 2000 Saab 9-5 (the lower end one with a mild turbo, not the performance version), but I think it fits most all the Saabs in that timeframe and perhaps some other cars as well. I attached the OpenScad file as well.  
Stick a long screwdriver or rod through the holes to give you leverage to remove the retainer ring.  
Again, it's over-built. Doesn't need to be so thick or with as much infill. It's also about 1cm taller than it absolutely needs to be.

I wear glasses. Specifically, titanium rimless glasses. The kind with the thin flexible arms.  
When I go to see a 3D movie, keeping the plastic 3D specs given to me by the theater on my face becomes a hassle. They always fall off, and I have to reposition them several times during the movie.  
This is a design for the common realD 3D glasses used by most theaters. The clip slides onto the arms of the 3D specs, and the arm of my glasses fit into the notch on the bottom, keeping them nice and stable.

Printed in PLA with 20% infill.  
The infill percentage likely doesn't matter all that much on a part so small.

Logo de playstation.
En este caso se tiene el logo de playstation en forma de collar con un pequeño toque personal (tiene mi apodo usado en los videojuegos). Las aplicaciones de la impresión 3d son muy variadas y con este ejemplo se puede ver una de ellas donde la impresión en 3d esta vez se utilizó para crear algo que es simplemente cosmetico. En si, no creo que haya límites para la impresión 3d, mientras algo pueda ser modelado con cualquier tipo de herramienta, ese algo podra ser impreso en 3d. Este modelo fue creado con la ayuda de la herramienta tinkercad. Playstation logo.
In this case we have the playstation logo as a necklace with a little personal touch (it has my nickname used in video games). The applications of 3D printing are varied and with this example you can see one where 3D printing this time was used to create something that is merely cosmetic. In itself, I do not think there are limits for 3d printing, while something can be modeled with any tool, that something can be printed in 3D.
This model was created with the help of tinkercad tool.

This is a clip for an IKEA JANSJÖ lamp for use with 2020 aluminum extrusion, such as the type used on the LulzBot TAZ printers.  
The design is an adaptation of an existing design for 8020 extrusion.  
I simply kept the same body, and re-sized the back "mushroom" down to fit.  
The part is a snug fit when printed in PLA, but should be able to be inserted without need of tools. Seems to be an even tighter fit when printed in ABS, requiring some extra force.

Print with me default settings of three shells and 20% infill.  
Printing with less shells may make the back "mushroom" more flexible and easier to insert, but the part will also be more likely to pop out if positioning the lamp at an extreme angle along the length of the extrusion.  
Printing in ABS versus PLA also seems to yield a part that is a little more rigid.
To commemorate TechShop Going 24/7, I have created a printable (preferably in Glow-In-The-Dark) medalion. Print thousands and stick them to your bedroom ceiling! The night will be magical!

remixed_from.title: 2015 Flashforge Creator Pro Universal Spool Holder

description.text: A spool holder for spools with 20mm axles. This is for the late 2014-2015 versions of the Flashforge Creator Pro, with the slot spool holders.

This is best printed on it's side, with supports enabled at 45 degrees.  
This was inspired by Davedfx's Universal spool holder, but I modelled the entire thing myself in Sketchup.  
IMPORTANT - PLEASE ENSURE that you have MEASURED your spools and that they fit correctly BEFORE printing with this part (or any other for that matter). Your spool should sit INSIDE the lip and the end, so it can't slide off or wobble. Measure the inside of your spool first (Top Tip: Use a discarded piece of filament to do this!)  
If your spool is a different size, try using Sketchup to modify my design to suit your spool!

comments.text: I went to change spools on my new printer only to find the spools I bought from Amazon (Hatchbox ABS) had must smaller holes in the center.  I saw this model and thought "Perfect!"

title: iPhone 4 tripod mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated with 1mm ridges so the fit can be tight 4/3/11.
This is for mounting your iphone4 on a tripod. Charging is possible while being held by the tripod.You can also stand your iphone in different ways.
Mounting your iPhone to a tripod can make a big difference when trying to make a watchable movie.
A 1/4 inch Wood insert Nut found at Lowes is mounted in the plastic to give a secure attachment to the tripod.
Please make sure that it holds your iPhone tight before putting it at any dangerous angles or upside down.
The holder was drawn/rendered? in sketchup and imported to ac3d then exported to .stl .
I am very new to this so if something isn't the way it is expected please leave a message. My first print from the Rapman 3.1 was made on Feb 23. Thanks to all in the 3d printer community for all the help you have left in forums ect.

Print on your 3d printer with your favorite settings and filament.
Buy a 1/4 inch insert nut, screw it in the large hole on the bottom. Heating the nut gets it to screw in easily without damaging your print. Make sure the plastic holds your iPhone tight before giving gravity a shot at taking it away. Not sure about 3d printers and how their variety affects sizes to a fraction of a mm.

comments.text: Yessir, this is the one. Simple, prints nicely. I happen to have 1/4 x 20  "T nuts" around here which is the perfect base anchor screw. There was a couple of slight modifications to make to suit my iPhone 4 but they are mods designed in. Two little ridges need to be removed with a file to widen the slot to fit my fat old 4 but they are gone in seconds. Installing the nut means opening the hole right through. If you drill slightly smaller than the neck of the nut it will crush into place and remain there. Very nice Variador!

Like many people I have become obsessed with collecting amiibo figures lately and needed some way to display them. This is my take on a modular display system for amiibo figures. You can print out a simple backdrop display, make an enclosed display cube, or even stack multiple cubes to form a unique display structure. The figures are held securely to the base, and can be read by your Wii U or 3DS while in the display.

I recommend printing out the amiibo_holder_test_print file first to make sure your figure will fit properly before printing out the whole base. The figure should be held securely in place with the clip. Once you dial in the dimensions, transfer them to the base_regular.scad file and generate a new stl to print. ---------------To make an enclosed display cube---------------
-1 display base (regular or large)
regular displays will fit most amiibos
-4 post_two_panel
-1 top_section
-1 top_retainer
-Create a custom image for your background and print on card stock or photo paper (display holds a 85mm X 87mm image)
-Cut out side, front, and top panels out of clear plastic sheet. If you still have your amiibo boxes, you can recycle them for this display.
Cut your plastic to these dimensions (may vary):
-Front/Back Panel 85mm X 87mm
-Side Panels- 65mm X 87mm
-Top Panel- 85mm X 64mm ---------------For simple background display---------------
1- display_base
2- post_single_panel
1-top_single_panel
-Create a custom background as mentioned above For stacking displays, just use an extra base in place of one of the top sections. For the majority of figures, the "regular" size base will work. But for larger figures such as Bowser, you will need to print the "large" base. Charizard should also fit but I am not 100% sure since I do not have one yet. I included the nameplates of all the amiibo figures up to Wave 4 in a zip file. I also included the nameplate.scad file so you can generate your own.
I used white acrylic paint on the raised lettering. I have also done a 2 color print with my single extruder printer. The "Zelda" and "Sheik" nameplates were made by pausing the print and changing the filament before the first. lettering layer started. Its a fairly easy process and gives a nice look to the nameplates. I included all the openscad files for each part so you can modify as needed. Make larger and/or taller displays for irregular figures, or increase the slot thickness to allow for thicker plastic panels, etc..
This is my first openscad project and I tried to make them easy to read. But I would appreciate any feedback.

Avooq has partnered with FeoArt to bring you the 3D Printable Nespresso pod rack as seen on Kickstarter and FeoArt.com. The pod rack system is designed to be printed in two parts and then assembled together via a neat friction fit. Place the pod rack inside a cupboard, under a cupboard and even on the wall, its up to you! Assembly Instructions:

  • Print both rack halves.

  • Press the two parts together.

  • Apply double sided tape or command strips (if you want to remove it later) of at least 1mm thick to the back of the assembled parts.

  • Stick to any vertical or horizontal surface and fill with your coffee pods.

  • Enjoy!
    • If you want the original Abucus pod rack, find it at www.feoart.com.au. Another Avooq creations, creation............................ with FeoArt. Find Avooq, for more great 3D Printable ideas and solutions.

comments.text: Found the problem.. On the G and probably any of the other letters your having trouble with, there are places that cross over.. Uncross them. Be sure to click Design and flush caches on Openscad any time you modify the dxf.. Any broken letter you tried to print will be stored. Flushing the cache will force it to reload.. I am clicking the I made one tab so i can post a picture of how to fix it

title: Coffee Filter Holder - Easy Access - By HakualDesign

description.text:
This is a coffee filter holder for filters used when brewing filter-coffee / american coffee designed to allow easy access every time you reach for a filter to put into the coffee maker. By special design in the slanted bottom holding the paper filters the next filter is slightly more elevated than the next and as a result more reachable than the next filter. This makes it super-easy to take the filter as is sticks up a little more then the consecutive filter..   
This Rev 1 version is in three parts (printed in one go) and need to be glued together using super-glue or other glue applicable for the material you use to print the thing. / HakualDesign

remixed_from.author: nigeljohnson73
remixed_from.title: Rubber band gun - no screws required

description.text:
with the original wheel design when loading rubber bands, the rubber band would get stuck between the wheel and pin, that caused the wheel to stuck.
so i created a different wheel with a groom to catch rubber bands.
and also made arcs to make the part stronger. there are two versions:
Ver1 - need to print 2 times and glue (no support needed)
Ver2 - Need to print once with support i have included the original files, if anyone wants to customize it.

comments.text: I would like to point out printing this with HIGH infill. I used 36° 40% infill in CraftWare, using two halves... and it exploded in my face missing my eye for a few centimeters. Two things broke: a tooth of this wheel (double tooth) and the blocking tooth of the trigger, all the rubber bands were shot towards me at the same time
comments.author: ephestione

comments.text:
Pla? Better use abs/petg...
And general recommendation is increase outline/perimeter shells for stronger parts (3 or 4 atleast).... infill above 25% only specific parts/usages will benefits from higher infill.....
Hope all is well and you will continue the journey of 3d printing...
comments.author: ephestione

comments.text: The great thing is you can just print the two halves without support and then not even bother to glue them together the tension of the rubber bands will keep them aligned. Works great but skinnier rubber bands are a must for a full 6 shots.
comments.author: Codyacehardware

comments.text:
when i load the forth and fifth rubber band the first is caught between the pin and the wheel,
that what happened to me.

remixed_from.author: cylgom
remixed_from.title: Velux DKL 05 AI 12X spring holder replacement part

title: Velux DKL curtain wiretrack replacement part

description.text: This is a replacement for part of the wiretrack of a Velux curtain. I think the curtain may be called DKL 05 AI 12X, but I am not sure. In Denmark Velux windows are pretty common, and lots of people may have a curtain like this. The design of the curtain wiretrack makes it wear the original parts out pretty fast. I have had to change the wires twice in 10 years, and now had to change the guides, as the wear made them wear the wires as well. Its bad design, but at least you can now print a replacement! Also, if you have such a curtain, you may want to check out the replacement for the spring holder of the wiretrack, by cylgom.

I recommend printing as the model is layed out, as that means the visible side gets the smoothest surface. The models has both a left and a right side - you obviusly only need to print the one you need. (You slicer should be able to delete one of the parts for you).  
Printed in 0.2mm layer height, solid, worked well for me. It uses about 8 gram of material, and gets quite robust.  
If you life in a hot country, you may want to print in ABS, as PLA may get to hot.  
This is a very small thing, with a number of details, so you may need to file a bit afterwards, or adjust the hole for the screw, to make it fit perfectly.

comments.text: Hi, I just wanted to say "Thank you very much". I had the same issue as you had ! The wire is cutting the plastic part. When the plastic is totaly cut it finish against the aluminum rail. And finally this one cuts the wire..... The the curtain  wont close anymore.
